summary: This is a transcript of a conference before Judge Richard M. Berman in the Southern District of New York regarding the criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein (19 CR 490). The discussion focuses on bail arrangements, victim notification, Epstein's sex offender status, the relevance of the 2007 Florida non-prosecution agreement (NPA), and the legality of the New York prosecution. The hearing sets a schedule for bail submissions and arguments.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The accused in the sex trafficking case. His bail, sex offender status, and the applicability of a prior non-prosecution agreement are central topics.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: Presiding judge for the conference. He asks questions about victim notification, Epstein's sex offender status, the Florida NPA, and sets the bail hearing schedule.

persons.name: Reid H. Weingarten
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein. Argues that the New York prosecution is a 're-do' of the previously resolved Florida case and that the NPA provides immunity.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein. Provides detailed arguments about the scope of the Florida NPA and its implications for the New York case, referencing ongoing CVRA litigation.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: Appears to be the lead prosecutor for the government in this hearing (first name not provided in text). Argues the NPA does not bind the Southern District of New York and discusses victim notification and evidence from the recent search.

persons.name: Pitman
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who handled Epstein's initial presentment, arraignment, and preliminary bail discussion earlier on the same day.

persons.name: Marrah
persons.context: Judge presiding over the CVRA (Crime Victims' Rights Act) litigation in the Southern District of Florida, referenced in discussions about the NPA.

events.title: Initial Conference in SDNY Case
events.description: Court conference before Judge Berman to discuss preliminary matters in the criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein, including bail, victim notification, and the Florida NPA.

events.title: Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: An agreement resulting from a prior investigation where Epstein pleaded to a state offense and federal prosecutors declined to prosecute. Central to the defense's argument that the NY prosecution is barred.

events.title: Epstein's Florida State Prosecution
events.description: Referenced as the source of Epstein's sex offender status, resulting in him being classified as a high-risk (Tier 3) offender in New York.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Townhouse
events.description: The government conducted a search of Epstein's residence on East 71st Street over the weekend prior to this hearing, uncovering materials discussed as relevant to bail and his sex offender status.

events.title: Scheduled Bail Hearing
events.description: Bail hearing scheduled for 10:00 a.m. before Judge Berman, with written submissions from defense due July 11 and government response due July 12.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York
East 71st Street (Epstein's townhouse residence in Manhattan)
Southern District of Florida (jurisdiction of the NPA)
keyFacts: The defense argues the New York prosecution is a 're-do' of the conduct investigated and resolved by the 2007 Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), which they claim granted Epstein immunity.
The government contends the Florida NPA does not bind the Southern District of New York, especially since one count involves New York-based victims and conduct not covered by the agreement.
Epstein is classified as a Tier 3 (high-risk) sex offender in New York as a result of his 2008 Florida state prosecution.

A recent search of Epstein's New York townhouse uncovered materials the government finds 'extremely concerning' for bail purposes, which the defense suggests are 'ancient' or involve consenting adults.
The court excluded time from speedy trial calculations until the July 15 bail hearing to allow for preparation of submissions and effective representation.
